item.title: AI Is Going to Eat Your Bandwidth
item.description: By: John Shepler Human communication might not dominate telecom usage for much longer. It started when computers began sharing data over phone lines and sped up when broadband internet connected almost every computer. Even though people currently use the internet for websites, messaging, social media, videos, backups, and work, machines will soon be the primary users, communicating amongst themselves. The Rise of Artificial Intelligence Artificial intelligence, or AI, has been subtly infiltrating our lives for decades, likely since computers emerged.

item.title: The Rush To Cloud Service Data Centers
item.description: Many companies are moving away from managing their own servers and rapidly shifting towards public data centers. This article explores the reasons behind this trend and its potential future. Cost savings have always been a major driver for companies considering data center colocation. Instead of investing in their own data centers, companies can move their equipment to a colocation facility. These facilities provide economies of scale by housing servers and network devices from multiple companies, sharing the costs of cooling, power, security, and bandwidth.

item.title: Colocation Hosting Offers Lower Costs and More
item.description: By: John Shepler Traditionally, medium to large businesses have relied on their own data centers. While this might still be the best option for some, there are benefits to moving some equipment and data to a colocation hosting facility. Let’s explore why this could be advantageous. What Exactly is Colocation? Colocation implies having multiple operations in a single location, and that’s essentially what it is. Initially called carrier hotels, colocation facilities housed equipment from various service providers within a building managed by a carrier or a third party.
